Posts.Title: tumors showing, chemo not working, turning 25 kita barsco1963

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2013 09:19PM HeyJude wrote: Loving this post; so nice to hear about our lives for once rather than the cancer. I'm 53, recently married (2009!) and am the wicked step mother to a 21 year old daughter attending university in Vermont. I am the VP of Human Resources for an Internet company in NYC but currently on partial disability - working about 15 hours a week until they replace me. I joined the BC ranks in 2006 at Stage 2B and thought I had it beat until last January when I couldn't breathe and discovered I was now Stage IV: liver and pleura and a few assorted lymph nodes around collar bone. Ironically, I had just completed a manuscript for my book, "Breast Left Unsaid" when I was thrown back into the world I thought I had escaped. I published my book in October (or Boobtober as I like to call it) and I guess I'm a writer now. Which I think suits me better. I've been doing live readings and getting excellent feedback - so its a nice way to spend my time instead of stressing about corporate nonsense. I'm on oral chemo (Affinitor) and Aromasin and doing great except I can't really eat decent portions of anything. I am planning several trips this year: London & South Africa - and planning a big party for friends and family on Memorial Day. Ups and downs for sure, but SO GLAD to know I can always come here and find friends who just know. I love you all.  http://breastleftunsaid.com Jude

Posts.Title: Lost a friend nancyh SusanR

Posts.Content: HeyJude wrote: Hello Mets Sisters - I'm going on 4 months on Afinitor/Aromasin and trying to be hopeful about my next scan in March, but having breathing, fatigue and eating issues that while not debilitating, are starting to keep me homebound more than I'd like. This week the breathing issues worsened and I'm going in for a CT scan tomorrow; looks like the right lung is not expanding properly (last year was the left - pleural effusion). Anyway - I'm tired of having to be the general contractor for this disease and pull all the data together myself. Has anyone ever had any luck at one of the Cancer Treatment Centers of America? Or some other cancer center that treats the whole person and not just the cancer? I have been to MD Anderson in the past and they are awesome, but I live in Connecticut, so it's not convenient. Any insights? thanks and I hope your day is the best it can be. X0X0 Dx Stage IV, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Cancer Treatment Centers of America experience? HeyJude HeyJude

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2013 02:17PM HeyJude wrote: thanks Chickadee! I just found the thread; sort of what I suspected. LuvRVing - I've been to Sloan although not since Stage IV and honestly, they didn't really have a treatment plan that included anything other than chemo. there was no "integrative" approach. I could try them again, but I'd be inclined to try Dana Farber this time. I just feel like cancer doctors focus solely on the cancer and ignore the rest of you and what keeps you well. Onward!

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2012 03:37PM HeyJude wrote: I've never bought a really nice, decadent purse. I go to Kohls and buy fake leather bags I can spill things on, or order Baggalini's with a million zippers for travel. I always look into the windows of stores where I see women plunking down huge sums for Coach or something else crazy expensive; always seemed over the top to me. Now that I know I can buy something nice and don't need to save and it really doesn't matter what the heck I spill - I may just have to go to mall with my sister and see if I can find something ....?
